name: Lower Fulton Creek
description:
Introduction

This page describes the lower section of Fulton Creek. This is a committing section of the canyon with some fun rappels, deep pools, and interesting water features. Of particular note is a terrific waterslide mid-canyon into a deep punchbowl. Lower Fulton, on its own, is probably a half-day adventure.

  • Upper Fulton Creek (aka Classic Fulton) is shorter separate section of the canyon and is described on its own page. It is possible to run both the upper and lower sections of this creek in a single trip, but expect a much longer day out. The middle section of the creek linking the two is described on the Upper Fulton page.
  • Watershed: 8mi^2. Highest point in the watershed is East Rock at ~4270' elevation. Expect to see about twice as much water as Upper Fulton.

Approach

Just north of Triton Cove State Park, turn left off Hwy 101 onto Seamount Dr. Follow the road upwards for 1.25mi to a pullout on the right with room for several vehicles. Note that the road gets very rough after the pavement ends. High clearance recommended; use extreme caution with low-clearance 2WD vehicles.

  • Apparently, some canyoneers have been parking at the end of the pavement and either hiking or carpooling up the road. While technically legal to park here, there a number of private homes extremely close by and the presence of cars may cause locals to wonder what you're up to and/or suspect you're up to no good. To alleviate their concerns, it may be better to park 2WD vehicles elsewhere (ex: Triton Cove State Park -- Discovery Pass required) and carpool up to Fulton in a high-clearance vehicle.

Hiking In

From the pullout, walk up the road about five minutes and climb over a berm onto an old logging road. Make your way through an old clear cut and descend a ridge into the canyon. As you near the tree line, bear off to your right/north and cross a gully to the next ridge following a faint game trail. Drop down the far side to the entrance of Lower Fulton. R1 is a short walk downstream.

Descent

Technical Notes

  • DCL = Down Canyon Left.
  • DCR = Down Canyon Right.
  • Beware running Lower Fulton early in the season as there are a number of siphons. A few of the obstacles encountered could be quite dangerous / difficult to overcome in high water. It may not be possible to escape the canyon until below R6. Do not rely on log anchors being present. A bolt kit and small folding saw may be recommended for the first team through in a given season.
  • All jumps and slides should be scouted in advance to ensure the water is deep enough and there are no submerged obstacles. Jumping is a leading cause of canyon injury (i.e. broken ankles and legs).
  • There are a number of short downclimbs that are not listed in the beta below.

Descent

  • R1: Downclimb into a pothole DCR to a log anchor. Rappel 35ft down a cool spiraling chute into a chamber/pool underneath a giant chockstone.
  • J1: 5ft drop from bottom of spiraling chute. The rope from R1 can be extended to scout the pool. It may be better to pull the rope for R1 from the top of the jump as the water is quite deep below.
  • J2: Downclimb to a shallow jump (~3ft) into a small pool. Use caution as the pool is not deep. This likely will need to be a rappel in higher flow.

Make your way through a narrow low-angle trough into the next big pool. Beyond, there's a short walk to the next obstacle.

  • S1: Amazing 35ft beautiful slide, with a 6ft vertical drop at the bottom into a very deep punchbowl. (Or rappel from fallen log DCR.)
  • Swim the pool below S1, then downclimb into the next pool. (This might be a rappel depending on water levels. Also possible shallow jump.)

A large logjam blocks the exit of the next pool. In 2022 a partner assist was required to climb out. More logs appeared in 2023 and a partner assist was not necessary. The next rappel comes immediately.

  • R2: Rappel 30ft from the logjam. (If the logs blow out, this drop will likely require bolting. It's also possible to rappel a short distance to a ledge and jump. (It might be possible to jump from the top? Pool below was about 7ft deep in 2023.)

Just ahead, enter the giant boulder garden:

  • 10ft pour-over. Bypass / downclimb DCL.
  • R3: 15ft. Near the center of the boulder garden, rappel to a lower level DCR from a log jam.
  • Ahead, the creek diverts in two directions around a giant house-sized boulder. The right side was an easy scramble around in 2023.

Continue downstream for a short distance. Bear DCR to reach:

  • R4: 20ft down a ramp from a single bolt DCR.
  • R5: 15ft from the top of a chockstone wedged between the canyon walls. Anchored on large tree creek-center well back from the top. Pool directly below the rap is not deep enough to jump, but launching further out might be possible? (This drop might be a good candidate for bolting in future.)
  • R6: The Dragon's Den. Ahead, the creek appears to be blocked by a huge boulder. Climb up to a tree DCL and rappel 40ft into a huge cave-like space underneath the boulder. This is a neat chamber with a hidden waterfall. To exit: crawl through a narrow 4ft tall gap underneath a second suspended chockstone (this one the size of a small car). Be aware: this gap may be blocked by wood and debris. It may be prudent to send a scout down to investigate (prepared to ascend back out) and make sure the way is clear. In 2023, the exit was completely blocked, but we were able to knock out enough debris to squeeze through. (In high water or if the exit is blocked, scramble further up the slope DCL and use a different tree to rappel back in downstream of the second chockstone.)
  • 10ft low-angle slide DCR. In low water conditions, it will be dry and can be downclimbed carefully.
  • R7 35ft from single bolt. Upon arriving at the top of the pitch, the creek diverts around both sides of yet another large boulder. Downclimb around the DCL side to find the bolt creek-center on the downstream side of the boulder, making a nice line down the drop. The rappel drops into a mini chest-deep pothole, then clamber out to rappel the rest of the way down. Swim out through a short water-filled narrows.

Exit

Below the final rappel, the canyon abruptly opens out. There's a nice place DCL to de-wetsuit.

  • On the DCL/north side of the creek, a very nice, well-maintained trail heads off downstream. Do not go this direction! The path leads quickly onto private property. Plans are currently afoot to contact the local land owner regarding access. This page will be updated when new information becomes available. (With a good exit and car shuttle, Lower Fulton would be amazing.)
  • Instead, exit the creek abruptly DCL, and make your way directly north, bushwhacking up a ridge. The distance and elevation gain back to the road is relatively trivial, but it is steep and unrelenting. Follow the path of least resistance, keeping to a northerly course to stay on timber company land. Near the rim, thicker vegetation takes over (reminiscent of English hedgerows) and you may find yourself wallowing or tunneling armadillo-like through the brush making excessive grunting noises. Keep going and eventually prevail as you break out onto an overgrown logging grade near the rim. Follow this climber's left a few hundred feet, then bushwhack over to the road. So far we have not identified anything resembling a "good" route. Just keep going, take breaks as needed, and, eventually, you will prevail. The total elevation gain is about 500ft. Upon intersecting Fulton Creek Road, turn left and walk back to your waiting vehicle (~2min). Declare victory.

Red tape

Be aware: Lower Fulton is on private timber company land. Access could be rescinded at any time, so please treat the area with respect and practice your best Leave No Trace.

Please stay on timber company land and do not follow the trail downstream upon exiting the canyon.

Beta sites

Trip reports and media

Background

Lower Fulton was first descended in Sept 2022 by Kevin Clark, Hereward Cooper, and Alex Danielson. We ran both Upper and Lower Fulton, exiting just before sunset.

In 2023, a second descent team: Kevin Clark, Clint Clow, Emily McEntire, Trey Schutrumpf, and Eric Rutz finished exploring the bottom of the creek and discovered the exit trail.
